Introduction

Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is a clinically asymptomatic, premalignant condition characterized by the production of a monoclonal immunoglobulin (M protein) by clonal plasma cells.  MGUS typically precedes more severe plasma cell disorders (eg, multiple myeloma) and is often discovered incidentally.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



The pathogenesis of MGUS likely begins with genetic changes (eg, mutations affecting cell cycle regulators [eg, cyclin D1], translocations involving the immunoglobulin heavy chain [IgH] locus) in a plasma cell, leading to clonal proliferation and production of M protein.  The clonal plasma cells comprise <10% of cells in the bone marrow and are generally nonaggressive.  Patients have no evidence of end-organ damage (eg, CRAB features [hyperCalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions], hyperviscosity, hepatosplenomegaly) characteristic of multiple myeloma.



The risk of MGUS increases with age, particularly in patients age >50.  First-degree relatives of patients with MGUS or other plasma cell disorders are also at increased risk, suggesting a genetic predisposition.

Clinical presentation



Patients with MGUS are typically asymptomatic.  The condition is often discovered incidentally when the M protein is detected on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) while evaluating for other unrelated conditions (eg, elevated total serum protein on routine laboratory evaluation).

Diagnosis



If elevated total serum protein is detected on routine laboratory evaluation, SPEP should be performed to better characterize the proteins present in the serum.  SPEP is an agarose gel electrophoresis that separates serum proteins based on weight, shape, and net charge.  Albumin, normally the most abundant serum protein, is always detectable as a spike on SPEP.  The presence of several different immunoglobulin spikes is suggestive of polyclonal gammopathy, which can be due to chronic infection.  In contrast, the presence of a single spike (ie, "M spike") is suggestive of a clonal plasma cell disorder.  Further workup with serum immunofixation can confirm the isotype of M protein (eg, IgA, IgM, IgG) present.



MGUS is defined by the following:



  • <3 g/dL of serum M protein
  • <10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow
  • No clinical findings related to the clonal proliferation


Other laboratory findings (eg, complete blood count, serum creatinine and calcium levels) should be unremarkable.  Imaging is generally not required for the diagnosis of MGUS unless there are symptoms suggestive of multiple myeloma or another plasma cell disorder (eg, anemia, lymphadenopathy).  In such cases, a skeletal survey, MRI, or PET/CT scan may be necessary.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of MGUS includes other disorders associated with elevated serum protein, including:



  • Chronic infections (eg, HIV, chronic viral hepatitis):  Plasma cells produce a variety of immunoglobulins in response to pathogenic proteins, resulting in polyclonal gammopathy (ie, no M spike) on SPEP.
  • Clonal plasma cell disorders:  are associated with production of monoclonal immunoglobulins or monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains.  These disorders include:
    • Multiple myeloma:  is distinguished from MGUS by the presence of ≥10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow and evidence of end-organ damage (ie, CRAB features).
    • Smoldering myeloma:  is an intermediate stage between MGUS and multiple myeloma.  Similar to MGUS, CRAB features are absent, but SPEP shows ≥3g/dL of serum M protein.
    • Waldenström macroglobulinemia:  is characterized by the presence of IgM M protein (ie, not IgA or IgG isotypes) and symptoms related to hyperviscosity, lymphadenopathy, and/or splenomegaly.
    • Immunoglobulin light chain amyloidosis (ie, primary amyloidosis):  occurs due to the deposition of immunoglobulin light chain fragments (amyloid proteins) in tissues, often causing organ dysfunction (eg, nephrotic syndrome, heart failure).

Management



Because MGUS is a premalignant condition, management, which includes the following, involves close surveillance for disease progression to multiple myeloma or other plasma cell disorders:



  • Regular clinical assessments
  • Serial SPEP and immunofixation to evaluation for increasing serum M protein
  • Serial complete blood count and serum chemistries (eg, creatinine, calcium) to evaluate for end-organ damage (eg, cytopenias due to bone marrow infiltration with clonal plasma cells, hypercalcemia due to lytic bone lesions)


The frequency of clinical assessments and laboratory evaluations depends on various factors that increase the risk for disease progression (eg, high serum M protein at diagnosis, non-IgG isotype, rapid rate of increase of serum M protein concentration).  Patients should also be educated about the symptoms of progression, such as bone pain, unexplained weight loss, fatigue, and recurrent infections.

Prognosis



MGUS has a generally favorable prognosis, with a low risk for progression to multiple myeloma or other plasma cell disorders.  Although the majority of patients with a plasma cell malignancy have a history of MGUS, only a small percentage of patients with MGUS develop a plasma cell malignancy (the annual risk of progression to multiple myeloma is approximately 1%).  Most patients with MGUS remain asymptomatic without disease progression for years or decades.

Summary



Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is an asymptomatic, premalignant condition characterized by the production of a monoclonal immunoglobulin (M protein) by clonal plasma cells.  MGUS is often discovered incidentally and is considered a benign condition.  However, because it is associated with a risk for progression to multiple myeloma or other plasma cell disorders, patients require close surveillance.
